title: Quiz 5: Microbial Metabolism
description: Test your understanding of microbial metabolism, including enzymatic activity, catabolism vs. anabolism, and respiration pathways.

questions.question: Match the metabolic term with its definition:

pairs.right: Sum of all chemical reactions in an organism

questions.explanation: Catabolism breaks down (releases energy); Anabolism builds up (uses energy).

questions.question: In the aerobic respiration of glucose, which process produces the most ATP?
questions.explanation: The Electron Transport Chain (oxidative phosphorylation) produces ~30-34 ATP, far more than Glycolysis or Krebs.

questions.question: A specific substance that an enzyme acts on is called its ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Enzymes bind to specific substrates at their active sites.

questions.question: Order the stages of Aerobic Carbohydrate Catabolism:
questions.explanation: Glucose -> Pyruvate (Glycolysis) -> Acetyl CoA -> Krebs -> ETC.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors that influence enzyme activity? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Enzymes are proteins sensitive to temp and pH, and activity depends on substrate availability.
questions.hint: Think about what can denature a protein.

questions.question: What is the final electron acceptor in aerobic respiration?
questions.explanation: Oxygen is the final electron acceptor, combining with H+ to form water.

questions.question: Fermentation requires oxygen to produce energy.
questions.explanation: Fermentation is an anaerobic process; it does not require oxygen and uses organic molecules as the final electron acceptor.
questions.hint: Do yeast need air to make alcohol?

questions.question: Match the nutritional category with its energy/carbon source:

richContent.content:
CategorySource
PhotoautotrophLight / CO2
ChemoheterotrophChemical / Organic

pairs.right: Uses Light for energy and CO2 for carbon
Uses Chemicals for energy and Organic compounds for carbon
Uses Light for energy and Organic compounds for carbon
Uses Inorganic chemicals for energy and CO2 for carbon

questions.question: Oxidation is defined as the:
questions.explanation: Oxidation is the removal/loss of electrons (OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain).

questions.question: Enzymes are used up in chemical reactions and must be constantly replaced.
questions.explanation: Enzymes are catalysts; they are not used up and can be reused.
questions.hint: Can a key open a lock only once?
